PERSONAL OBSERVATION
I support the drive to develop a single powerful voice to
speak for the TV licensees and to confront CPB on their
behalf. Public TV is under attack and it must respond as
^effectively and as fast as it can. Whatever is necessary
to stop the steam-roller and hold the fort must be done.
Reorganizing to maximize the fire power of lay board members
appears to be the best bet for ETV at this critical moment.
But television is not all of public broadcasting! And the
rest of the enterprise is the responsibility of NAEB,
together with the continuance of various professional
activities of importance to the whole field.
Organizing to represent the TV licensees in matters affecting
programming and program distribution is the thrust of the
Rogers' initiative and the point'of the Palm Beach Accord.
And, while he is concerned about Radio and recognizes the
importance of professional services, these are not in the
main stream of his concern and, at best, are matters to be
dealt with at a future time. Given all that, where does
NAEB go?
This question forces us to think about our mission and what
sort of structure is most suitable. Form follows function.
NAEB's mission is to advance the use of communications
technology for social purposes; it follows that we should
dedicate our future task to a more important question than
survival. Jim Fellows has suggested that this be the validity
of the telecommunications concept. Institutions interested
in public uses of modern communications technology will
increasingly employ a comprehensive approach - multiple channel
delivery systems, multiple media production and utilization
capacities and related services.
Mr. Fellows' memo points out that we already have evidence to
indicate our institutional members view this as a growing trend:
attendance at the Telecommunications EBI, requests for
supporting papers and reference materials, interest in expanding
the facilities program to make other technology eligible for
federal support - all these suggest that there is a growing
recognition that it is no longer sensible to place exclusive
emphasis upon radio and television broadcasting.
